raw_text: Over the past few years, there has been cons id erable progress in the ability of manually created large-scale grammars, such as the English Resource Grammar (ERG, Copestake and Flickinger (2000)) or the ParGram grammars (Butt et al, 2002), to parse wide-coverage text and assign it deep semantic representations
clean_text: Over the past few years, there has been considerable progress in the ability of manually created large-scale grammars, such as the English Resource Grammar (ERG, Copestake and Flickinger (2000)) or the ParGram grammars (Butt et al, 2002), to parse wide-coverage text and assign it deep semantic representations.

raw_text: These tools have been developed to serve an Arabic Lexical Functional Grammar parser using XLE (Xerox Linguistics Environment) platform as part of the ParGram Project (Butt et al2002)
clean_text: These tools have been developed to serve an Arabic Lexical Functional Grammar parser using XLE (Xerox Linguistics Environment) platform as part of the ParGram Project (Butt et al 2002).

citing_paper_authors: Aoife, Cahill | Tracy Holloway, King | John T., Maxwell III
raw_text: The experiments reported in this paper use the English LFG grammar constructed as part of the ParGram project (Butt et al, 2002) .This system incorporates sophisticated ambiguity management technology so that all possible syn tactic analyses of a sentence are computed in an efficient, packed representation (Maxwell and Kaplan, 1993)
clean_text: The experiments reported in this paper use the English LFG grammar constructed as part of the ParGram project (Butt et al, 2002).

raw_text: We parse a tree bank with the XLE platform (Crouch et al, 2008) and the English grammar developed within the ParGram project (Butt et al, 2002)
clean_text: We parse a tree bank with the XLE platform (Crouch et al, 2008) and the English grammar developed within the ParGram project (Butt et al, 2002).

citing_paper_authors: Timothy, Baldwin | Mark, Dras | Julia, Hockenmaier | Tracy Holloway, King | Gertjan, van Noord
raw_text: Aspects of this research have often had their own separate fora, such as the ACL 2005 workshop on deep lexical acquisition (Baldwin et al, 2005), as well as the TAG+ (Kallmeyer and Becker, 2006), Alpino (van der Beek et al, 2005), ParGram (Butt et al, 2002) and DELPH-IN (Oepen et al, 2002) projects and meetings
clean_text: Aspects of this research have often had their own separate fora, such as the ACL 2005 workshop on deep lexical acquisition (Baldwin et al, 2005), as well as the TAG+ (Kallmeyer and Becker, 2006), Alpino (van der Beek et al, 2005), ParGram (Butt et al, 2002) and DELPH-IN (Oepen et al, 2002) projects and meetings.

raw_text: A full system using the Lexical-Functional Grammar (LFG) parsing system XLE and the grammars from the Parallel Grammar development project (ParGram; (Butt et al., 2002)) has been implemented, and wepresent preliminary results on English-toGerman translation with a tree-labeling system trained on a small subsection of the Europarl corpus
clean_text: A full system using the Lexical-Functional Grammar (LFG) parsing system XLE and the grammars from the Parallel Grammar development project (ParGram; (Butt et al., 2002)) has been implemented, and we present preliminary results on English-to-German translation with a tree-labeling system trained on a small subsection of the Europarl corpus.

raw_text: In the work described in this paper, we employ the XLE platform using the grammars available for English and German from the ParGram project (Butt et al, 2002)
clean_text: In the work described in this paper, we employ the XLE platform using the grammars available for English and German from the ParGram project (Butt et al, 2002).

raw_text: This problem was illustrated using a German LFG grammar (Rohrer and Forst, 2006) constructed as part of the ParGram project (Butt et al, 2002) .The grammar is implemented in the XLE, a gram mar development environment which includes avery efficient LFG parser and a stochastic disambiguation component which is based on a log linear probability model (Riezler et al, 2002)

raw_text: Within the ParGram project (Butt et al, 2002), Kim et al (2003 )wereable to directly port the argument optionality re lated rules from a Japanese grammar to Korean.However, to our knowledge, no one has implemented an analysis that has been applied to a large number of typologically, geographically, and genetically diverse languages
clean_text: Within the ParGram project (Butt et al, 2002), Kim et al (2003) were able to directly port the argument optionality related rules from a Japanese grammar to Korean.

raw_text: The only rule-based approach to German LFG-parsing we are aware of is the hand-crafted German grammar in the ParGram Project (Buttet al, 2002)
clean_text: The only rule-based approach to German LFG-parsing we are aware of is the hand-crafted German grammar in the ParGram Project (Buttet al, 2002).

citing_paper_authors: Joachim, Wagner | Jennifer, Foster | Josef, van Genabith
raw_text: In order for our approach to work, the coverage of the precision grammars must be broad enough to parse a large corpus of grammatical sentences, and for this reason, we choose the XLE (Maxwell and Kaplan, 1996), an efficient and robust parsing system for Lexical Functional Grammar (LFG) (Kaplanand Bresnan, 1982) and the ParGram English grammar (Butt et al, 2002) for our experiments
clean_text: In order for our approach to work, the coverage of the precision grammars must be broad enough to parse a large corpus of grammatical sentences, and for this reason, we choose the XLE (Maxwell and Kaplan, 1996), an efficient and robust parsing system for Lexical Functional Grammar (LFG) (Kaplanand Bresnan, 1982) and the ParGram English grammar (Butt et al, 2002) for our experiments.

citing_paper_authors: Joachim, Wagner | Jennifer, Foster | Josef, van Genabith

clean_text: The ParGram English LFG is a hand-crafted broad-coverage grammar developed over several years with the XLE platform (Butt et al, 2002).
